C=E9dric Beust ? wrote:

>>Quite interesting that neither TestNG and JUnit4=
 does not take into
>>account IDE or reporting needs.
>>
>>It is quite obvi=
ous that array-based parameter generator will not
>>scale to large test sui=
tes. So, framework should provide some way to
>>supply test data lazily.
>>=

>>From other hand if you think of IDE it should be possible to run
>>just =
specific test or only selected test cases. o, it seems that there
>>should =
be some random-acess API, which iteterator just does not provide.
>>
>>Also=
 note that one would be interested to know how many test cases
>>in the giv=
en data provider as well as a readable name for each test.
>>    
>>
>I exc=
hanged a few emails with JB about that, and my take on "data names" is
>bas=
ically: I don't see the need.
>
>If a test method being fed by a data provi=
der fails, it will clearly say
>something like "Expected 42 but got 41". Fr=
om that point, it's pretty easy
>to trace which data from the data set caus=
ed this error and act on it.
>  
>
  That is exacly the case I'm talking ab=
out. In more or less complicated 
example test data may include number of i=
nput parameters and failed 
expectation on primitive value (such as numeric=
 os string assertion) is 
completely unrelated to these parameters. Moreove=
r it is quite possible 
that you'd have a side effect and test is failing o=
n some other reason 
(like internally swallowed runtime exception or someth=
ing similary weird).

>Actually, I would probably not even care about that =
myself: I would rerun my
>tests, put a breakpoint on any assertion thrown a=
nd let the IDE show me
>exactly where and when the test fails. Whether this=
 test method was fed data
>from a DataProvider or from somewhere else is ir=
relevant to fix the test.
>  
>
  Don't you think it would be a mistake to =
tell the users how they 
should work? :-)
  Besides, if the test failed on =
build or continuous integratino server 
you would have to rerun test locall=
y with your breakpoint, which would 
be quite waste of time in my opinion, =
because you should know that is 
failed from the report.

  Another quite p=
ractical use case for test names is that they can be 
potentially used to g=
et better understanding what part of the 
functionality is broken. Especial=
ly if this feature is used for some 
integration-level regression tests tha=
t may potentially cover wide range 
of functionality.

  regards,
  Eugene
=
